714085f-b.text:
421 East 6lst Street, north side, between York and First Aves., showing the Col. Smith House (also known as the Adams Mansion). This house was built in 1799 by Colonel Smith, a son-in-law of President Adams. One version states that it was built in 1777 by Peter Pra Van Sairt for a stable to his residence and he sold (1765) the mansion, stables and other buildings to Col. Wm. S. Smith. The latter failed in business and his stable became a tavern and was used as such until 1830 when Jeremiah Fowle purchased it, whose daughter occupied it until 1906. The Consolidated Gas Company sold this building in December 1924 to the Colonial Dames. This set consists of 4 views
taken at the same time.
February 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

714080f-b.text:
421 East 6lst Street, north side, between York and First Aves. This house was built in 1790 as a wedding gift to one of John Adams' daughters. At the time of this picture it is occupied by the Museum of the City of New York. In 1931, however, the Museum will move uptown to its new building on the east side of Fifth Avenue from 103rd to 104th Streets, and this house will
be oocupied by the Colonial Dames of America.
September 15, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, more of a side view.
September 15, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

724851f-a.text:
York Avenue (name changed 1928 from Avenue A), east side, north from and including 6lst Street. On the N.E. corner of 62nd Street is the pumping station of the Consolidated Gas Company, and behind it may be seen the old American Malting Company plant, on 64th Street east of the Avenue. It now belongs to George Ehret, and will be demolished three years from the time of this picture. Above 64th Street may be seen trees on the grounds of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.
September 15, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

714079f-c.text:
(1)
421 East 6lst Street, north side, between York (Ave. A.) and First Aves. Old stone building shown, is the Col. Smith Mansion, and was built in 1799. Note the gas holders of the Consolidated Gas Co.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; showing a closer view.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Another perspective of the same view. Note a portion of Cornell Medical College and New York Hospital Centre, in the distant background.
September 23, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

714084f-a.text:
421 East 6lst Strect, north side, between York and First Aves. This view shows the eastern extremity of the Col. William S. Smith Mansion, which
was built for his wife, the daughter of John Adams, in 1799.
About 1900.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
